ajmc.commons package#

ajmc.commons contains all the utilities (helpers, functions, objects, hard-coded variables) which are common (i.e. which must be accessible) to task-specific repositories. These include notably:

  • file_management utilities, which allow to handle files systematically in the ajmc’s data organisation (see notebooks/data_organisation.ipnb for more) and to retrieve information from the various project spreadsheets.

  • arithmetic.py contains helper maths function, mainly to deal with intervals, which are a common object in our Canonical format (of which more below).

  • docstrings.py centralizes common function and class docstrings in a single place and provides a decorator to retrieve them easily.

  • geometry.py provides helper functions and an object, Shape, to deal with geometrical objects such as contours and bounding boxes.

  • image.py provides helper functions and an object, AjmcImage, to deal with images.

  • miscellaneous.py receives everything which doesn’t fit anywhere else. It notably contains generic functions and decorator, lazy objects for efficiency etc…

  • variables contains all the hard-coded variables such as PATHS, COLORS, SPREADSHEET_IDS, CHARSETS and many more.

Submodules#

This module contains basic arithmetic functions.

ajmc.commons.docstrings module#

This file contains generic docstring chunks to be formatted using``docstring_formatter``.

ajmc.commons.docstrings.docstring_formatter(**kwargs)[source]#

Decorator with arguments used to format the docstring of a functions.

docstring_formatter is a decorator with arguments, which means that it takes any set of kwargs as argument and returns a decorator. It should therefore always be called with parentheses (unlike traditional decorators - see below). It follows the grammar of str.format(), i.e. {my_format_value}. grammar.

Example

This code snippet:

@docstring_formatter(greeting = 'hello')
def my_func():
    "A simple greeter that says {greeting}"
    # Do your stuff

Is actually equivalent with :

def my_func():
    "A simple greeter that says {greeting}"
    # Do your stuff

my_func.__doc__ = my_func.__doc__.format(greeting = 'hello')

Note

Best practice is to name your arguments in compliance with docstrings.docstrings in order to simply call @doctring_formatter(**docstrings.docstrings).

ajmc.commons.file_management module#

File management tools and utilities, such as moving/renaming/replacing files, get paths…

ajmc.commons.file_management.check_ocr_gt_spreadsheet_conformity(comm_id: str)[source]#

Checks that a commentary’s ocr gt directory contains the same pages as the spreadsheet.

ajmc.commons.file_management.check_via_spreadsheet_conformity(comm_id: str, check_comm_only: bool = False) → Tuple[Set[str], Set[str]][source]#

Verifies that via_project actually contains the page ids listed in sheet_page_ids and vice-versa.

This function is used to make sure that the pages marked as groundtruth in spreadsheets are actually present in the respective via_project and vice-versa. If there are differences between the sets of via and spreadsheet pages, prints a logging.error. In any case, return the two sets of difference.

Parameters:

  • comm_id – The id of the commentary (e.g. sophoclesplaysa05campgoog). Ids are listed in ajmc.commons.variables.ALL_COMM_IDS.

  • check_comm_only – Whether to check only the pages where only commentary sections are annotated.

Returns:

  1. The difference sheet_pages - via_pages.

  2. The difference via_pages - sheet_pages.

Return type:

A tuple containing two sets of str

ajmc.commons.file_management.clean_all_ocr_runs_outputs_dirs()[source]#

Cleans all ocr/runs/xxxxxxx/outputs dirs from lace outputs and other weird files.

ajmc.commons.file_management.data_sanity_check()[source]#

Performs a sanity check on ajmc base data.

This function notably checks: - That the ajmc’s folder structure is respected (i.e. that requested files and folders exist). - That the data is in the correct format (e.g. that images have the right extension). - That data is compliant with spreadsheets.

ajmc.commons.file_management.find_replace_in_all_comm_dirs(file_rel_path: str, old_pattern: str, new_pattern: str, check: bool = False)[source]#
ajmc.commons.file_management.get_62_based_datecode(date: datetime | None = None) → str[source]#

Returns a 62-based code based on the date and time.

Examples

>>> get_62_based_datecode(datetime(year=2021,month=1, day=1, hour=1, minute=1, second=1))
"111111"
>>> get_62_based_datecode(datetime(year=2021,month=12, day=31, hour=23, minute=59, second=59))
"1cvnXX"

This function is mainly used to generate a unique id for each OCR run, based on the date and time. It takes the form of a 6 digits numbers, where each digit is a letter or a number. * The first digit correspond to the last number of the year (e.g. 1 for 2021). * The second digit correspond to the month (e.g. 1 for January, B for december). * The third digit correspond to the day of the month (e.g. 1 for the 1st, A for 11, K for 21…). * The fourth digit correspond to the hour (e.g. 1 for 1am, A for 10am… etc). * The fifth digit correspond to the minute (e.g. 1 for 1min, B for 11min… etc). * The sixth digit correspond to the second (e.g. 1 for 1sec, C for 12sec… etc).

Note

Base 62 is set to default, as it allows for displaying hours, minutes and seconds in a single digit. It corresponds to the 10 arabic numbers,the 26 latin lower-case letters and the 26 latin capitals.

Parameters:

date – The date to be converted to a 62-based code. If None, the current date is used.

Returns:

The 62-based code as a string.

ajmc.commons.file_management.get_metadata_spreadsheet() → pandas.DataFrame[source]#

ajmc.commons.file_management.int_to_x_based_code(number: int, base: int = 62, fixed_min_len: bool | int = False, symbols: str = '0123456789abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ') → str[source]#

Converts an integer to an x-based code.

Examples

>>> int_to_x_based_code(3,base=2,symbols='01') # Binary code for 3
'11'
>>> int_to_x_based_code(11, base=12, symbols='0123456789AB', fixed_min_len=3) # Base 12 code for 11
'00B'
Parameters:

  • number – The number to be converted

  • base – The base of the code (default: 62)

  • fixed_min_len – If int, the minimum length of the code, prepending symbols[0] if necessary.

  • symbols – A string of symbols, mapped to integers (starting from 0) to be used to represent numbers in the

  • (default (resulting code) – NUMBERS_LETTERS)

Returns:

The x-based code as a string.

ajmc.commons.file_management.move_files_in_each_commentary_dir(relative_src_path: str | Path, relative_dst_path: str | Path, base_dir: Path = PosixPath('/Users/sven/drive/_AJAX/AjaxMultiCommentary/data/commentaries/commentaries_data'))[source]#

  • relative_dst_path – relative path of the destination file/folder, from commentary base_dir (e.g. 'ocr/groundtruth')

  • base_dir – The base directory to commentaries data. Use variables.COMMS_DATA_DIR to access the default value.

ajmc.commons.file_management.read_google_sheet(sheet_id: str, sheet_name: str, **kwargs) → pandas.DataFrame[source]#

A simple function to read a google sheet in a pd.DataFrame.

Works at 2022-09-29. See https://towardsdatascience.com/read-data-from-google-sheets-into-pandas-without-the-google-sheets-api-5c468536550 for more info.

Parameters:

  • sheet_id – The id of the spreadsheet, i.e. the part of the url after ‘spreadsheets/d/’. Check commons.variables.SPREADSHEET_IDS for examples.

  • sheet_name – The name of the sheet in the spreadsheet, for instance ‘Sheet1’ or olr_gt.

Returns:

The sheet as a pd.DataFrame.

ajmc.commons.geometry module#

Basic geometrical operations and objects.

class ajmc.commons.geometry.Shape(points: Iterable[Iterable[int]] = None)[source]#

Bases: object

The basic class for contours, bounding boxes and coordinates.

Shape objects can be instanciated directly from points. Other constructors are Shape.from_numpy_array(), Shape.from_center_w_h()``and ``Shape.from_xywh().

property area: int#
property bbox: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]]#

A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

classmethod from_center_w_h(center_x: int, center_y: int, w: int, h: int)[source]#

Creates a Shape from center_x, center_y, w, h, where center_x and center_y are the coordinates of the center and w and h represent width and height respectively.

classmethod from_numpy_array(points: ndarray)[source]#

Creates a Shape from a numpy array of points.

Parameters:

points – Array which can be coherced to a shape (N,2) where N is the number of points

classmethod from_xywh(x: int, y: int, w: int, h: int)[source]#

Creates a Shape from x, y, w, h, where x and y are the coordinates of the upper left corner, while w and h represent width and height respectively.

property height: int#
property width: int#

Gets the bounding box in [x,y,w,h] format, where x and y are the coordinates of the upper-left corner.

property xyxy: Tuple[int, int, int, int]#

Returns the coordinates of the upper left corner and the lower right corner of the bounding box.

ajmc.commons.geometry.adjust_bbox_to_included_contours(bbox: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], contours: List[Shape]) → Shape[source]#

Finds the contours included in bbox and returns a shape objects that minimally contains them.

Note

This function is mainly used to resize word-boxes. It therefore discards the contours that would make bbox taller (i.e. longer on the Y-axis). This is helpful to avoid line-overlapping word-boxes.

Parameters:

  • bbox – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • contours – A list of included contours

Checks whether bboxes are overlapping with each other.

Parameters:

ajmc.commons.geometry.are_bboxes_overlapping_with_threshold(bbox1: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], bbox2: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], threshold: float) → bool[source]#

Checks whether the overlapping (intersection) area of two bboxes is higher than threshold x union area.

Parameters:

  • bbox1 – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • bbox2 – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • threshold – The minimal proportion of the union area to be included in the intersection area.

ajmc.commons.geometry.is_bbox_within_bbox(contained: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], container: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]]) → bool[source]#

Checks whether the contained bbox is entirely contained within the container bbox.

Note

Included means included or equal, not strictly included. For any bbox r, we have is_bbox_within_bbox(r, r) == True.

Parameters:

  • contained – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • container – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

ajmc.commons.geometry.is_bbox_within_bbox_with_threshold(contained: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], container: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]], threshold: float) → bool[source]#

Asserts more than threshold of contained’s area is within container. Is not merged with are_bboxes_overlapping for effisciency purposes.

Parameters:

  • contained – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • container – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

  • threshold – The minimal proportional of contained which should be included in container.

ajmc.commons.geometry.is_point_within_bbox(point: Iterable[int] | ndarray, bbox: Tuple[Tuple[int, int], Tuple[int, int]]) → bool[source]#

Checks wheter a point is contained within a bbox.

Note

Included means included or equal, not strictly included.

Parameters:

  • point – Iterable containing x and y coordinates (e.g. (123, 87)

  • bbox – A tuple of two (x, y) tuples representing upper-left and lower-right coordinates.

ajmc.commons.image module#

Basic operations and objects for image processing.

class ajmc.commons.image.AjmcImage(id: str | None = None, path: Path | None = None, matrix: ndarray | None = None, word_range: Tuple[int, int] | None = None)[source]#

Bases: object

Default class for ajmc images.

Note

The center of AjmcImage-coordinates is the upper left corner, consistantly with cv2 and numpy. This implies that Y-coordinates are ascending towards the bottom of the image.

Parameters:

  • n – the number of elements in each chunk

ajmc.commons.miscellaneous.timer(iterations: int = 3, number: int = 1000)[source]#

Decorator with arguments. Computes the execution time of a function.

timer is a decorator with arguments, which means that it takes any set of iterations and number as arguments and returns a decorator. It should therefore always be called with parentheses (unlike traditional decorators).

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils module#

This file contains unicode variables and functions which serve processing unicode characters.

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.chunk_string_by_charsets(string: str, fallback: str = 'latin')[source]#

Chunk a string by character set, returning a list of tuples of the form (chunk, charset).

Example

>>> chunk_string_by_charsets('Hello Γειά σου Κόσμε World')
[('Hello ', 'latin'), ('Γειά σου Κόσμε ', 'greek'), ('World', 'latin')]
Parameters:

string (str) – The string to chunk.

Returns:

A list of tuples of the form (chunk, charset).

Return type:

list

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.count_chars_by_charset(string: str, charset: str) → int[source]#

Counts the number of chars by unicode characters set.

Example

count_chars_by_charset('γεια σας, world', 'greek') returns 7 as there are 7 greek chars in string.

Parameters:

  • string – a NFC-normalized string (default). For NFD-normalized strings, use count_chars_by_charset_nfd.

  • charset – should be 'greek', 'latin', 'numeral', 'punctuation'.

Returns:

the number of charset-matching characters in string.

Return type:

int

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.count_chars_by_charset_nfd(string: str, charset: str) → int[source]#

Counts the number of chars by unicode characters set.

Example

count_chars_by_charset('γεια σας, world', 'greek') returns 7 as there are 7 greek chars in string.

Parameters:

  • string – a NFD-normalized string. For NFC-normalized strings, use count_chars_by_charset.

  • charset – should be 'greek', 'latin', 'numeral', 'punctuation'.

Returns:

the number of charset-matching characters in string.

Return type:

int

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.harmonise_unicode(text: str, harmonise_functions: ~typing.Tuple[~typing.Callable[[str], str]] = (<function harmonise_punctuation>, <function harmonise_miscellaneous_symbols>, <function harmonise_ligatures>), harmonise_space_chars: bool = True) → str[source]#
ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.is_charset_string(string: str, charset: str, threshold: float = 0.5, strict: bool = True) → bool[source]#

Returns True if more than threshold of chars in string are in charset, False otherwise.

Parameters:

  • string – self explanatory

  • charset – should be 'greek', 'latin', 'numeral', 'punctuation' or a valid re-pattern, for instance r'([ô-ÿ])'

  • threshold – the threshold above which the function returns True

  • strict – if True, only chars in charset are considered, if False, chars in charset, 'numeral' and 'punctuation' are considered.

ajmc.commons.unicode_utils.is_charset_string_nfd(string: str, charset: str, threshold: float = 0.5, strict: bool = True) → bool[source]#

Returns True if more than threshold of chars in string are in charset, False otherwise.

Parameters:

  • string – a NFD-normalized string. For NFC-normalized strings, use is_charset_string.

  • charset – should be 'greek', 'latin', 'numeral', 'punctuation'.

  • threshold – the threshold above which the function returns True

  • strict – if True, only chars in charset are considered, if False, chars in charset, 'numeral' and 'punctuation' are considered.
